div.head: TO THE CANDID READER.
div.p: _A Small part of this Subject, many years since had drop'd from my pen: But looking at some opportunities upon the Argument, I thought some things more considerable might be deduced; and applying my self further, at times of recess, I felt it grow and multiply un|der my imagination: Nor left I it then (the matter being so pregnant in it self) till I form'd it into such limbs and pro|portions as you now see it. Modesty after this, invited me to cover it, and to cut off many impertinences, and purge some humour, that sa●e, I confess, un|handsomely upon it.

What is now presented, I hope will appear a genuine and unforc'd Moral, which though drest in Drammatique Ornament, may not displease, in the reading, persons of ingenuity, such whose nature is not to create prejudice, where they intend a recreation. And in the confidence of that, I do not repent the superstructures I have made, my pains, nor expences that have attended to bring it to this. It is now publique to satisfie the importunity of friends, I will onely adde, it is like to be the last, for in my resolve, nothing of this nature shall after this, engage either my pen or invention.

The reason why I make no particu|lar Dedication to any Friend, is, because I aim my general respect to all, whose favours and civilities have oblig'd me. At this none will be offended, where
none hath the precedence: And to con|clude with the most serious truth, I know not any, that love me so little, whom the payment of my so mean ad|dresses would satisfie, as to clear me up|on the account of his friendship. Let this suffice at present from him, that is

list.head: Persons.
list.item: Travers a Lawyer, servant to Mammon and Honoria.

div.head: ACT. I.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: _TIS not far off, 'Ile aske this Gentleman.
Can you instruct me, sir, where the great
Lady Aurelia Mammon lives?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: Yes sir, I can.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: Pray do me the civility.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: Have you
Affaires with her, my friend in black.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: Have you
Relation to the Lady, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: She ownes me
A Gentleman-usher, with your pardon Sir,
Are not you inclining to a Scholar?

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: I have spent time i'th Academy.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: The Academy?
Another beggar,
I did think so by your serious face, your habit
Had almost cosened me, and your hair, they are
Of the more Court edition, this is
A beggar of the upper forme of Learning,
Your business with my Lady,

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: If you please
To prepare my access—

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: 'Tis to no purpose,
My Lady keeps no Library, no food
For booke-worms, I can assure you that,
Learning is dangerous in our Family,
She wo'not keep a Secretary for fear
Of the infection.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: Does she keep no foole?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: Yes, yes, and knaves;

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: I thought so,
In which classe is your name, I beseech you?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: We enjoy equal priviledges, indeed the knave
Makes somewhat more on's office, but my Lady
Is not so nice, so we can bring Certificates
That we are sound, and free from the infection
Of book's, or can lay down our understandings,
And part with that unnecessary stuffing
I'th head, (you know my meaning) or renounce
The impious use of humane art and knowledge,
We are in a capacity of imployment;
Perhaps you may, on these terms be admitted
With your Philosophy, and things about you,
To keep her horse, de'e observe?

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: A faire preferment!

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: The fittest here for men of art, or if
You can keep counsell and negotiate handsomely
The amorous affair of flesh and blood;
(There you may exercise your parts of Rhetorique.)
How lies your learning that way? 'tis an office
Many grave persons have submitted to,
And found it a smooth path to court preferment,
But she is here, I'le leave you to your fortune.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: With me, your business?

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: The Lady Honoria, Madam, by me humbly
Presents her service, and this paper to
Your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: The Lady Honour? 'tis
Some borrowing letter.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: This is not civill.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I am so haunted with this mendicant
Nobility at every ebbe of fortune.
I must be troubled with Epistles from e'm.
What's here? — you are, a Scholar.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: I have studied the artes,

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Your Lady writes as much, and would commend you
To my inployment, but I want no Chaplain.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: If you did, I cannot flatte●, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I have known wiser men converted by Preferment.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: They were things that had no Soules,
Or use of that bright Entelecheia
Which separates them from beasts.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I did expect
Hard words, and do commend the pure discretion
Of your most learned tribe, that think themselves
Brave fellowes, when they talk Greeke to a Lady;
Next to the Goth and Vandall, you shall carry
The bable from Mankind, pray tell your Lady,
Learning is out of fashion in my Family,

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: Why should you be an Enemy to Arts?
The Lamps we wast, and watches, that consume
Our strength in noble studies, are ill paid
With this disdain, your smile would make us happy,
And with your golden beame strike new day
Through learnings universe.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: You but loose your time,
I know you are writing some prodigious volume
In praise of hunger, and immortall beggery.
This may in time advance you to a Pedant,
To whip the Town-top's, or gelded Vicaridge,
Some forty Markes per annum, and a Chamber-naid
Commended by your Patron.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: Y'are not worth
My anger, I should else—

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: What my sweet Satyre?

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: Present your Ladyship with a glasse, a true one.
Should turne you wild to see your owne deformity.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I pretheeraile, now for a storme—

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: I wo'not loose my temper on such a trifle.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: But here are two come timely, to disperse
All clowdy thoughts, my diligent daily waiters.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Now Poetry be my speed! my noblest mistriss.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: What have you there, dear Mr. Fulbanke?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Lines, that are prou'd to express your beauty, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Bless me! turn'd Poet? I must tell you Servant,
Nothing in nature is more killing to me.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Umh! I see my Lady Mammon is no wit.
Do'e think I made e'm? I have an Estate, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I know you have fin'd for Alderman.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: They were a foolish Scholars o'the Town,
And I made my address to be confirm'd
In your opinion, they were wretched things,
And like the starv'd composer. The nine Muses
I have read, Madam, in a Learned Author,
Were but a knot of travailing, tawny gipsies
That liv'd by country canting, and old Songs,
And picking wormes out of fooles fingers, which
Was palmistry forsooth, and for Apollo
Whom they call'd Father, a poor silly Piper,
That kep't a thatch'd house upon Cuckolds Hill,
Not far from Helicon, or old Bride●well,
Where he sold switches, till his hut was burn'd
One night by a tinkers nose, that lay in straw there;
And he, for losse of this poor tenement,
Ran mad, from whence came all the mighty stir,
Of that, which we now call Poetick fury.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: 'Tis very likely.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Madam, be your leave,
I am a country-man, what should a man lye for?
I ken no Colledge learning, but I have
Been whip'd for latin in my dayes, that have I;
And have heard talke of the Philosophers stone;
Although I weare not velvet like his worship,
My heart's imbroyder'd with love and I
Defie the man that thinkes me insufficient
To do, whats fitting to be done between
You and I Madam, as the best what lack you
Finical-fartical-citt within the walls.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Take heed how you provoke me.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: I'le provoke any man living, in the way of Love.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Did all the Ladies sleep well?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: Yes and their Monkeys Madam, and have all
Their severall thanks, and services remembred
To your Ladiship— but Madam—

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: She has left us.
I'le find a time to make, you sensible—

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Me sensible?
I defy thee.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Be no● rampant, and thank Heaven
We are not arm'd.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: I scorne it.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Dar'st thou meet me?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Yes, the next day after Simon and Iude
I dare, when all your liveries go a feasting
By water with your gally foist and pot-guns,
And Canvas Whales to Westmin●ster▪ I am not
Affear'd of your green Robin-hoods, that fright
With fiery club your pitifull Spectators
That take pains to be stifled, and adore
The Wolves and Camels of your company.
Next whom the children ride, who innocent things,
What with the Gyants, and the Squibs and eating
Too many sugar-plumms, take occasion to
Perfume their Pageants, which your Senators
Ride after in full scent.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Thou horrid Lumpe
Of leather, course wooll, ignorance and husbandry,
Most pitifully compounded, thou that
Hast liv'd so long a dunghill, till the weeds
Had over-grown thee, and but ten yards off,
Cosen'd a horse that come to graze upon thee,
Thou miserable thing, that wert begot
By the whole Town, thou dar'st call no man Father,
Found in a hedge, but bred up in a stable,
Wherewith the horse thou did'st divide the bean's,
Dung like the beast, and wert as often curried.
Thus bred, at one and twenty thou wer't able
To write a legible Sheeps mark in t●rre,
And read thy own capitall letter, like a gallows
In a Cows buttock.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Suffer this?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: And more:
Fortune conspiring with thy own ill nature,
That durst be damn'd for Money, made thee rich,
And then the Countreys curses fatten'd thee,
Time, and thy sordid sins made thee at last
High-Constable, and now thou hast the impudence—

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Thou liest.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: Fear not me Gentlemen, I am your friend,
A friend to both your honours; here, be noble
You have a just cause, and a gallant Mistriss
Persons of your quality, to fight thus
For bloody noses, too't like Gentlemen,
And draw blood handsomely, he that gets the victory
Shall ha my Lady, and a pardon, though
It cost her half a Million, so I leave you.
Here will I stay, and observe both their valours.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: We are betraid.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: I do not like these tooles.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: It is not for my credit to be kill'd,
If he have but the courage to advance,
I am no Merchant-taylor of this World,
And yet he lookes less rampant. Sirrah Maslin—

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: I were best deliver up my cold iron, here.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: He does approach.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: And yet I wo'not. Fulbanke.
I am of thy opinion, we are both
Betraid; for my owne part, although I carry
No flesh that feares a sword; yet I do not
Affect to have devices put upon me.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Tis something thou hast said; this may be ● plot;
Some third man has projected by our ruines
To make his path smooth to my Lady Mammon;
And thus her Squire promotes it.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: A consp●racy!
I read it in the rascals face, too't quotha
Like Gentlemen● no, they sha'not laugh at me.
And my Lady had a mind to ha my throat cut,
She shall excuse me.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: To my wishes! but
I am not satisfied,
We can without some blood come off with honour,
You know th'affront was mine, and though I wod not
Have my revenge writ in too deep a crimson,
Yet something must be done, it will be publick,
And we may still be laugh'd at.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Thou saist right,
Things cannot well be clear'd without some blood.
I have consider'd, and you shall be satisfied,

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: So, I have made fine worke, the Bore will fight now.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: The credit of a wound will serve, thus then—

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Stay, I have a device will bring us both off.
Why may not we consent to give each other
A careless wound in the leg, or arme, and so
March off with honour?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: This knack was in my very thoughts, 'tis Ex'lent.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: But since I nam'd it first, 'tis my invention,
And I will strike the first blow,

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: hang't, I pass not,
But gently then, a scratch ith arme, or hands
Enough, a small thing does it, gently, oh!
Thou hast cut of my Sword hand, this is fowle play,
I cannot hold my toole now.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: But stoope to reach it,
I'l cut thy head off, Ith field we must
Use all advantages. This weapon's mine too.
Farewell, and say I have used thee honourably.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: Ha. ha. ha. are you hurt Sir?
I see the Alderman has outwitted you.
Let me see, ha? a scratch, a very scratch;
Beare up, there may be wayes to your revenge,
Leave not your applications to my Lady.
He counsells this, that will assist you — but
I ever thought your habit much beneath
The person that should court so great a Lady.
It smells too much ot'h ●eame, I know y'are rich.
Aire, aire your gold, and make your body clinkant,
The rest commit to fate, and me, consult
Your Taylor.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: And my Chirurgeon; Sir I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: You do not know, how I am contriving for you.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: That very word has cur'd me. I'le about it.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: So, when ther's no other mischief to be done,
Let them go on, and love my Lady Mammon;
I'le assist one, in hope the t'other may
Go hang himself, and then it will be hard
To judge, which of the two has the better fortune.

div.stage: Enter Honoria between Alamode and Collonell.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Bless me but with one smile, if you did know
With what devotion my Soul lookes on you,
How next to my Religion I have plac'd,
(If not above it,) your diviner beauty—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Your name is Alamode, a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Aba.
sp.l: 'Tis sweetned by Honoria's breath,

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I have
No stock of pefum'd words to court you, Madam,
Can you affect a man? A souldier?
When I have march'd upto a breach, which look'd
Like Hell with all his sulphurous flames about it;
My heart was fixt on honour, and I tooke
From gaping wounds the fleeting Soules about me
Into my owne, and fought with all their spiritis;
The mangled bodies that I trod upon,
(For now the dead had buried all the Earth)
Gave me addition to Heaven where, in,
My strong imagination I saw
Thee from thy Chariot dropping down a Garland.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: You are a Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I profess a souldier Madam.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: It appears a bold one; art thou come Alworth.
What said the Lady Mammon?

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: One that has some relation to her person.
They call him Alworth, and I have observ'd
She lookes on him with favour above a Servant,
He has not the impudence to court his Lady

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: So peremp●ory? what a strange monster wealth is?
I have but made a tryall of her friendship,
And had no meaning thou should'st leave me Alworth,
Depend upon my care, I know your parts;
And shall not be forgetfull of their merit.
But thou art come most seasonable to relieve me.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: I do not like their whispering.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: If you please, Madam, to absent your self,
Leave me to the excuse.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Do so, dear Alworth.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: I am happy when you command me service.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Be confident, I keep a silent register of all,
And shall reward them.

sp.speaker: Alw,
sp.l: Your own vertues guide you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: My Lady's gone.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: But has commanded me to let you know
Her resolution, she hath found you both
Ambitious of honour, both deserving,
And such an equall furniture of merit,
She has no art to reconcile her thoughts
Into one fortunate choice.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: 'Tis very strange.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: The Gordian, which great Alexander could not
By subtilty dissolve, his sword untwisted;
I use her own words, Gentlemen, you may
Inferre, that you must either quit your courtship,
Or by your selves agree, who best deserves her,
And dare do most to merit such a mistriss.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: How, best deserves her?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: And dare do most,

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: I should interpret this to fight for Honour.
But you can best expound, and so I leave you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: What sayes my perfum'd Alamode to this?
Will not a sword quite spoile your sattin Doublet,
And let in too much aire? your lips and language
Bath'd in the oyle of Gessamine will not carry her,
You have worne a sword thus long, to shew the hi●t,
Now let the blade appear.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: It shall. I have yet
No ague, I can looke upon your buffe,
And punto beard, yet call for no strong-water,
I am no Tavern gull, that want protection,
Whom you with oathes do mortifie and sweare
Into the payment of your ten pound surfeits;
Upon whose credit you weare belt and feather,
Top and Top-gallant. Go to your Landab—
It'h new Brothell, she's a handsome leverett,
If she deny free quarter, tear her trinkets,
Make Cu●●ice of the Matron, yet be friends
Before the Constable come in, and runne
Ot'h ticket for the dear disease.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Go on sir.
I will have patience three minutes longer,
To hear thy scurrile wit, and then correct it.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Answer but one coole question, if Honoria
Should possibly descend to think well of thee,
And by some philtre should be brought to love thee.
What Jointure could we make, what's the per annum?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Have you done yet?

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: 'Tis not impossible,
You may have a Catalogue of Town's and Leaguers
The Names of Bridges broken down, your nose
In time may keep them company in Landschape:
You will tell of Bulworke●, Barricado, Fort's.
Of outworkes, half moones, spurres, and parrapets
Of turnepikes, flankers, Cats and Counter-scarfs,
These things will hardly pawn with Jew or Christian;
But i'le come closer to you, you may have
In ready wounds some twenty, i'le admit,
And in diseases can assure her forty;
This wo'not do, she cannot eate a knapsack,
Or carry baggage, lye in your foule hutt,
And rost the pullen, for whose pretious theft,
You and the gibbet fear to be acquainted.
If you return into your wholsome Countrey,
Upon your honourable wooden legges,
The houses of Correction have but thinn
Accommodations, nor the Hospitalls.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: It does appear by all this impudence,
And little wit pi●fer'd, and put together,
You do not know me.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Cry your mercie, Sir.
You are a great Field-officer, are past
These petty things, but if these times preserve
Their smooth complexion, it wo'not be
Ten hundred thousand pistols to a ●●iver,
But you may run this gantlope once agen.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: You imagine you have stung me now, and that
I think my self concern'd in this keen character?
I tell thee (wretched thing,) thou doest not reach
A Souldier, 'tis a name, three Heavens above
Thy Soule to understand, and 'twere a sin
Would lessen our own worth, to make thee know it.
You are a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Very good.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Nay rather.
A very impious one, you shall confess it,
Or I will cut your throat, this is no canting.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Very fine.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Nay we know you are a fine Gentleman,
A Taffata-sattin-plush-embroydered-
Lac'd-scarlet-tissue-cloath-a-bodkin devill;
Pride is thy meat and drink, thy Library,
And thy Religion, thy new clothes only
Bring thee to Church, where thou dost muster, all
The fashions, and the trinkets, to the last
New button, upon which thy conscience sits,
And as the devill guides it, dost condemne,
Or save the people, that done, not the window's
Scape thee, for thou woot quarrell with the pictures,
And find fault with the Apostles, for not having
A better Taylor, these Sir are your vertues,
Your high, and holiday devotions.
What moral vices follow in the weeke,
Is best known to the devill, your close friend,
That keeps the Catalogue, yet one touch of them;
Thy lust has no bounds, when thy blood's a fire,
Thou leap'st all like a Satyre, without difference
Of kindred, or acquaintance; and were those
But summon'd, whom thy body hath infected,
They would stuffe an Hospital, and out-stinke the Pest-house.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: And yet I walke upon these poor supporters.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: How long the Chirurgeon knowes.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: These all my faults?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: No, those are but thy Peccadi●●ioes,
Thy ma●ice is behind, thou woot not take a bribe
To undo a Nation, sell thy Countrey men
To as many persecutions, as the devill
Or Dutch men had invented at Amboyna;
With all this stock of villany, thou hast
An impudence—

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: I'le heare no more,

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: A little i'le intreat you, all is but
A preface to your bearing, which must follow,
Your tribe will beare it.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Then have at you Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Y'are very nimble Courtier.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: As you see.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Good Mounsieur Quicksilver,
You may be fixt.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: And your arrear's be paid.

div.stage: Another Pass, Alamode down and disarm'd.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: What think you now?

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: It is your fortune Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Y'are at my mercie, aske your life?

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: I scorne it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I'le kill you then.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: A boy may do as much
At this advantage.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Will you not aske your life?

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: No 'tis not worth it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: And't be not worth your asking, 'tis not Worth
My taking at this posture, there's your weapon,
Rise, use it agen.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: It shall be thus to render it.
Though I was not so base to beg my life,
Yet since you have given it me, I scorne to imploy it
Against one that was the master on't,

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: This is gallantry.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: You taught it first.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: In spight of all the Widdowes in the World
We will be friends.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: I meet it Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: And for the Lady Mammon—

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Wee'l take our chance.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: A match, now let us to th' Tavern.

div.head: ACT. II.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: I Think I have brought your business we about, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Thou hast oblieg'd me everlastingly:
Nay nay, be covered, thou art my best friend.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: It was but Justice to advance your merit
With all the Retorick I had, for where
In prudence, could my Lady Mammon place
Her self with more advantage to her fame?
A widdow of a thousand pound per annum Jointu●
With some few present bagges of musty Gold,
Old Plate, and hungry houshold-stuff would serve
The Countrey well enough.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Excellent Phantasme

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: Where the report of building a Free-school
And now and then an alme-house for old women,
With five teeth and a half among sixteen,
Would make a mighty noise, and the poor hinds
Wonder, there's so much money left in nature.
The City is her only sphere of glory.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Right, very right.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: Here My Lady Mammon.
(Yours now as things are ordered)

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: May have high and noble waies to employ her treasures.
Do things above the vulgar admiration,
Surround the City with a wall of Silver,
Transmute dull Leaden-hall to Gold, rebuild
The great Cathedrall of St. Pauls with Porphyrie
And clap so bright a spire upon't, shall make
The Sea-man afar off wonder what new
And never setting starre, Heaven hath created
To make the day eternall in this Island.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: My own Phantasme.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: There is no end, Sir, of herwealth, if you
Have but the patience to spend, you may
Out-do the Roman Luxuries.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I'l give thee my Gold-chain.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: O'h no, it may do you better service, Sir,
'Bout your own neck hereafter; for all this
Infinite Treasure that she brings you, Sir,
What Joynture do you make her?
You are mortall.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I ha thought of that,
I will secure my whole Estate upon her?
Beside her own, I have no kindred, that
I care for, they are poor, and as my pride,
While I am living, will not look upon e'm,
At death, it will be wisdom to forget them.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: It would endeare my Lady much, if you
Surprize her with this act, before she think on'●.
I would have you do things gallantly —

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: You shall
Give the direction to my Counsell;

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: His name.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: A very honest able eminent person,
One Mr. Traverse, see it done your self.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.l: My Lady will take it well, without all do bt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: But shall I engage your trouble —

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: 'Tis an honour;
I'l give him order to dispatch all presently.
He is a very honest man you say.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: He's right, I know him intus & in Cute.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: My Lady, Sir, leave things to me.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: My most divine Aurelea!

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Dear Mr. Fulbanke,
I have no happiness but in your presence,
When shall the worke be perfect?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I was considering,
It would become the glory of my Bride,
To have some state, and triumph at our marriage,
I know the City will expect we should
Accept some entertainment, perhaps Pageants,
And speeches to congratulate our Nuptial.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: 'Twill please me much.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: There may be prejudice in these delay's,

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Oh Sir, the state is all; what thinks your Ladyship?
We will have tilting too, and feats of Chivalry
At Court where I'l defend my Aurelia Princess,
In the guilt armour that I mu●tered in,
And the rich saddle of my owne perfuming,
I'l have my squires, my plumes, and my devices,
And with my lance encounter the whole mirrour
Of Knight-hood, and compell the forreign Princes
To hang up all the Tables of their Mistrisses
As Trophee's to my most victorious Mammon.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: Without some cure he will be mad immedi|ately.

div.stage: Enter Alamode, reading a Letter, a Servant waits.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Present my humblest service to Honoria,
Say I am all obedience to her commands,
Were I in Heaven, this invitation
Would have the power to draw me thence, I kiss
Her fairest hand, this for your favour,

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Please you to know my Lady Sir?

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: If I mistake not the Lady Aurelia;
Widdow to the late high Treasurer, Sir
Omnipotent Mammon.
But are you Master of this rich Peru?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: She will please to owne me, ha?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: It is but Justice.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: A thousand streams of joy flow in your bo|soms,
I'l take some fortunate hour to visit you,
And with an humble lip print my devotions
On your white hand.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: You'l do me an honour sir.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Some high affairs compell this rude depar|ture,
But you have mercy to excuse your servant.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: VVhat heaps of words some men have got together

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: How do you like this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: These Courtiers are another sort of flesh-flies,
That haunt our City dames, but we must winke,
Or loose our Chatter?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: Bless the Body Politick.

div.stage: Enter Maslin in rich Cloths, but Antick.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: By your leave Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: VVhat Pageant's this?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: VVhere De'e think I have been, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: At the Brokers.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: At the Exchange by these silke-stockings,
Mr. Usher— a word to the wise,
If they will fit your rowling pin, they'r paid for;
Perhaps the wages you receive in your
Relation to my Lady, wo'not find you
Convenient vanities. Now I'me for you Madam.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: In good time.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: I wanted but your hand,
I could ha fitted you with gloves, but here are
Some trifles for the finger, you must weare
This Diamond, and this Ruby,

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: De'e understand
VVhat you do sir?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: And here's a casting Net of Pearl.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: A Carkane●? these will deserve—

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Tell not me of desert, I hate it perfectly,
Hang toyes and yellow rubbish that paid for e'm,
How De'e like my clothes?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Sir I am concern'd to thank you for these fa|vours.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: You? prethee away, I ha nothing to say to thee?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: We have no other gratitude sweet-heart,
But to invite him to our wedding.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Wedding? Phantasme.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: And you had come but half an hour sooner,
This very shape had don't.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Do not, do not make me mad too soone.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: You have been very bountifull, and we pray
Your noble presence at our Festivall,
Which we have deferr'd to be attended with
Some Triumph, such as may become the City,
And my dear Ladies honour, is't not so,
My America? look how the oyster gapes.
Leave him to chew his Countrey cud, come Madam.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: Sir I confess.—

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: And be hang'd, I am undone, and I could cry now.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: Sir,
You have been at a great charge to go without her,
Such rings, and Carknet, beside the cost
Of this fine habit? for your bounty, Sir,
Bestowed on me, the unworthiest of your Servants,
I have a gratitude, if you please to accept it.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: What is't? a halter or a knife to cute me,
Or a comfortable poison?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: 'Tis the first
You nam'd, a most convenient, neatly twisted
Halter, for I do see your inclinations,
And shall commend your fortidude, beside
'Twill shew a brave contempt upon their scorns.
And who know's, how the example, Sir, may spread
To cure some o●her mad men that love widdows.
You have my judgement and the cord for nothing,
Lose not the nick of the next beam you come at,
No way like this to be High-Constable.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Here, take my clothes; I will be mad, and hang
My self immediately; — and yet I will consider,
Till the ayre be a little warmer; when I have
Cut Fulbanks throat, 'tis but a hanging afterwards.
'Tis good to be ma●icious, and wise;
Some notable revenge would be worth all
My cost, and then a sico for the Devill.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: Please you to have a little patience
I shall acquaint my Lady that y'are come, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Before you go, dear Sir, I know your pru|dence
And neere imployment with my Lady, has
Endeer'd you to part ake some of her Counsells;
You shall obliege a very humble Servant,
To let me know how she affects, you reach
My meaning, by what motive am I sent for?

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: My Lady keeps the key of her own Cabinet,
But if you'l have my Judgement on the scheme,
I think my Lady will this day determine
Her choice, I encline the rather to this Judgement,
Because the Colonell is sent for too.
My attendance is expected, Sir, your pardon.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Ha musick.

div.stage: A song within praise of a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: My Lady will appear presently,
I'l give her knowledge, if you please.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Your favour, Sir,
You are learned beyond books, what's your opinion
Of my Lady, in relation to things at present?
What do you think of me?

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: My thoughts are much
Too narrow to conclude your worth, which left
An object for Divine Honoria's wisdom,
Must only take from her, a worthy character
And just reward.

div.stage: A song in praise of a Sold●er.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I like this preface.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: My noble Colonell, thy Servant.

div.stage: Enter Honoria attended, a Table set forth, with a Cabinet upon it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Excuse the trouble that I give you Gentle|men,
Y'are welcome, and thus knit into a freindship,
Your persons have more grace, and shine upon e'm.
Some chairs, pray sit. I see you both preserve
Your fair respects to honour, and I have
After some pause, and serious dispute
Within my self, collected now at last,
Upon whose person to repose my self,
My fortune, and my same, and since but one
(Where many may deserve) can weare the Gar|land
The loser must content himself with his fate,
And wait a kinder providence.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: 'Tis but Justice.

div.stage: She takes a wreath of Bayes from the Cabinet.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: This wreath of bayes, embleme of victory,
Must crowne his head to whom I fall a Conquest,
Forgive the Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Oh 'tis very pleasing,

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: I like it well, Madam, and commend your fancy.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: You, Sir, were bred up in the Schoole of ho|nour,
The Court, this may not unbecome your Temples,
Wise Courtiers are the Jewels of a Crown,
The Columnes and the ornaments of state,
Fitted with parts; and piety to act:
They serve the Power for Justice, not themselves;
Their Faith the Cabinet, in which is laid
The Princes safety, and the Nations peace,
The Oracles, and the mysteries of Empire;
Men borne above the fordid guilt of avarice,
Free as the mountain aire, and calme as mercy.
Borne without Eyes, when the poor man complains
Against the great oppressor, without hands,
To take the bloudy price of mans undoing,
But keeping at each sense a Court of Guard,
Draws fear from Love, and teaches good by example.

div.stage: She puts the Wreath upon the Colonell.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Divine Honoria.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: You must give me leave,
To try, how it becomes his brow; me thinks
VVith the same grace, in dwells upon his head,
Does he not look like mighty Iulius now,
When he returned triumphant from the Gaules,
Or bringing home the wealthy spoiles of Egypt,
Pontus, and Africa▪ allow him but
The same commands, and men to fight, why may not
His Valour equall what is fam'd in story,
Archiev'd by the great souls of Rome, and Carthage?
A soldier merits first to be called man,
By whom not only Courts but Kingdoms flourish,
Unto whose severall offices, the VVorld
Owes all the great and glorious names of honour.
How would the age grow ru●ly, and the soule
Of Common-wealths corrupt with ease, and surfeits,
Should not the sword call e'm to exercise,
And sweat out their unmanly Luxuries,
By acting things worth envy, even of Princes.
The honour of the Gowne without his sword,
VVill run it self into contempt, and Laws
Are not good made, but while the sword secures e'm.
The Court must weare no silke, nor the prowd City
Make the Sea groane with burden of her wealth,
Did not the active soldier, with expence
Of his dear blood, expose himself abroad,
Their convoy, and security at home.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I am transported.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Give me the same favour
To let me looke a little on this Chaplet,
To which I have annexed my self a Labell.
Me thinks the Trifle looks, as it had lost
Some Verdure since I took it from your heads,
The Courtier, and the Soldier both inviting
In such a high degree of merit, hinders
The progress I should make, but pardon me,
I shall soone quit the Labarynth.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: What's the meaning?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I would you were not two, or that one had
Less of desert, when you are both in ballance,
Have you no art, Gentlemen, to contract
Your selves into one person?

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: 'Tis not possible.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Think you so? it is worth the experiment,
Come hither Alworth.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Nay come nearer,
This is a Scholar, Gentlemen, and the cloud
He weares, remov'd, for he's no more a Servant,
May bring him into a civill competition:
Me thinks it fits him, your opinion?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: We are in a fair way to be ridiculous, what think you?
Chiaus'd by a Scholar?

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Are you in earnest Madam?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I repent not
The placing of it there, in him do meet
The Courtier and the Soldier, at least
He's not without the best capacity
Of both your worths, when they have brightest lustre.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: There is no remedy.
Would I had Mammon.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Gentlemen stay, & hear the Scholars character.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: No thank you Madam, we have heard too much,
Fortune has given you Lawrell, and us willow.
May your wreath flourish, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Soule of my muse! what active unknown fire
Already doth thy Delphick wreath inspire?
O'th suddain how my faculties swell high,
And I am all a powerfull Prophecie.
Sleep ye dull Caesars, Rome will boast in vain
Your glorious Triumphs, one is in my brain
Great, as all theirs, and circled with thy bayes,
My thoughts take Empire ore all Land, and Seas.
Proof against all the Planets, and the stroke
Of Thunder, I rise up Augustus Oake,
Within my guard of Lawrell, and made free
From age, look fresh still, as my Daphnean tree:
My fancy's narrow yet, till I create
For thee another World, and in a state
As free as innocence, shame all Poets wit,
To climb no higher than Elizium yet;
Where the pale Lovers meet, and teach the groves
To sigh, and sing bold legends of their Loves.
We will have other flights, and tast such things
Are only fit for sainted Queens and Kings.
All that was Earth falls of, my spirits free,
I have nothing left now, but my Soule and thee.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: VVhat means this Extasie? this was not meant,
Unless you use my favours with less insolence,
I can repent, and frowne e'm back to nothing.
Have you forgot your distance? can a smile
And this green trifle forfeit your discretion,
Or make me less, than when you were my Servant
I look you should be humble still,

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: Good Heaven!
What unexpected, most prodigious cloud,
With his black wings, hath in a minute veild
The brightest day, that ever smil'd upon me?
Did not you place it here?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: It is confest,
As an encouragement to your vertue, Sir,
No Conquest of Honoria, yet you triumph,
And make me blush as I had courted you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: O do not charge my thoughts with such a stain,
This might deserve your anger, and vouchsafe me
The boldness to say Madam, if you punish
My hasty application of your favours,
You gave me the encouragement to be guilty.
It is a tyrany to cherish Servants,
And punish their obedience.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: But when ●lattered by
Pride, which darkes the soule, you challenge
And measure the reward by your own fancy,
You loose the noblest recompence of service,
And merit but the hire of common duties;
'Tis possible, that Gold may satisfie
My debt to your imployment.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: Till this minute
I was not lost, but having heard this, Madam,
You must do something like a miracle
To save me now;— I dare contemne your Gold,
And am compell'd to aske your Justice, what
Action since I had reference to honour,
Look'd with a mercenary staine upon it?
Gold is a pay for soules of darke complexion.
I served you for your self, and since I'm thought
Beneath the merit of your smile, I'l make
My self above the price of sordid contracts,
For I can with as much ease despise your wealth,
As I can shift the ayre, I take my leave,
And can pray for you in a Wilderness.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Come back, this minute every cloud is vanish'd
That did present displeasing formes: I find
Thy soule is pure, forgive this Triall, thou hast
Deserved me best.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: I dare not understand you now.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: The language is not hard.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: I want a name, to call this blessing by,
Then I may kiss your hand, and may I not,
Madam approach your lip, and be forgiven?
Now I begin to doubt.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: My Faith?

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: That I am not awake, or if I be
That I am short-liv'd, and must soone dissolve
Under this storme of happiness; ha? 'tis come
And I have lost my courage o' the suddain.
Your pardon Madam, something gathers here
That wo'd surprize my heart. I am asham'd on't.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Who waits, contribute your best help to his
Support, convey him gently to his chamber,
Run for Phisitians, thy good genius guard thee.

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: I am not Worth your fears.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: And worth my love?

sp.speaker: Alw.
sp.l: That very word should cure me,

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I have been
Too much, I fear unkind, to both our dangers.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: VVAit at the door, my Clients are so numerous
And pressing with their suites, they almost stifle me.
Let me enjoy the aire of my owne Chamber;
I think I have lost some lungs in the last cause.
Let me indulge a little to repair e'm,
A glass of the Greeke wine, Th' Italian Merchant
Presented me, and let the Terme go on,
I'l drive the Law at leisure, and o're take it.
sp.stage: Clarke fills Wine into the glass.
sp.l: So so, this looks sprightly,
Be carefull of this Treasure, 'tis my blood,
VVast not one drop, upon thy life I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: VVast quothe?
You shall not prove a wast, I'l warrant you.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: So, so, remove.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: Sir your Idolaters, the Writs are come.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: The weather's ho●, let no more spirits enter,
Now like the soveraigne Bee, methinks I sit
●n my prodigious hive, surveying all
●y wing'd, industrious people, bringing honey,
●nd making wax more pretious than▪ a trade
●o both the Indies. My good Emissaries,
●nd faithfull spirits of the Law, descend
●o your infernall shades, untill I call you,

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: A Gentleman desires to speak with you Sir,
●rom the Lady Mammon.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Admit him.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: VVhat a fine thing this Terme is?
●nd what an ungodly time, the long Vacation?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: Sir, I'l not hold you long, I know you have business,
●here have past some overtures of love and marriage,
●etween your City Client, Mr. Fulbank,
●nd the Mistriss that I serve, the Lady Mammon.
●nd you should draw a Deed to settle on her
●is whole Estate, if she survive, as Joynture—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I understand you Sir.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: I am glad you do, this Sir is his desire,
●nd to have all dispatch'd with expedition.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: But the reason of my coming is
To desire you sir, to let all this
Alone, there is another thing, that will
Concern you more materially.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Your meaning?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: You are not married.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I enjoy a freedom.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: My Lady Mammon has a vast Estate,
And is a widdow, you do understand?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Her name is precicus to the VVorld.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: The VVorld's an asse, you look like wiseman,
You have a good face, and a handsome person
Under a Gowne, you have a good Estate too;
I am a Servant, that have credit with her,
By my relation; and I have no mind,
The City Mule, your Client, should breake
His back with burden of his gold; in short,
I wish you well, and if you have the confidence
To make a motion for your self, this high
And mighty widdow, may be yours; I'm plain.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Say you so?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: I'l bring her to you, and prepare her too,
Have I been tedious sir,

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: My better Angell!

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: Legions attend my Lady, trouble not
Your head why all this kindness from a stranger.
I had a revelation to do thus;
Have a strong faith, and think upon't, your Servant.
If within half an hour she visit you,
Think it no dreame, and thank me afterwards,
Now leave your wonder, and be wise.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Can this be true? 'tis not impossible.
This is a pretty vision would I had her.
If she appear I may believe, and prosper.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: The tide is coming in,
Mr. Maslin the High-Constable, a good man
And full of causes.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: What intrusion's this?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: I have given a sop to Cerberus your door|keeper.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: O' Mr. Maslin you are become a stranger.

sp.speaker: Mas,
sp.l: 'Tis not for want of love to be at Law.
Your worship knows, I am apt to trouble you,
And the whole County where I live.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Your business?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Sir, it is extraordinary, and I desire
Beside your learned worships fees, to pay
For expedition.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You speak reason.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: I do abound in reason, look you Sir
'Tis all of this complexion; here's a piece
For every day till the next Terme begin,
And two for every day it lasts.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Have a care of your health, good Sir;

sp.speaker: Mas,
sp.l: And you of your spectacles.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: What must I do for this?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Do? you must undoe
A friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: A Friend?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: We are all friends in Law, Sir,
Never did man suffer so fast an injury,
And therefore take him to your legall malice▪

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Has he kill'd your Father?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: VVorse, worse:

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Made a whore of your sister?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: VVorse than that:

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Ravish'd your wife?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: VVorse than all that, and yet this comes the neerest,
H●s cheated me of my wench; a widdow Sir
That has more money than all your profession
Has got, since the dissolution of the Abbeys.
In short, this is the Case, Fulbanke, the City
Gulfe has swallowed my Lady Aurelia Mammon.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: O Caniball!

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Devour'd my widdow, wife
That should ha been, this man I hate, this man
Must be undone, and there's part of the money.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: The Lady Aurelia Mammon?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: That very Polcat; but I must tell you Sir,
They are not married yet, if you have now
A dainty Devill to forbid the banes—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Although this be a case, more pertinent
To the Court Ecclesiasticall, yet,
Let me consult my Law-giver.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Sir, so I may
Be reveng'd, I stand not much upon't,
VVho has this Mammon, let the Devill take her,
Or your worship take her, 'tis all one to me.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Hum! I shall stretch a point of Law for you.
You shall have your desire, I do expect
Her presence instantly,

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Is that a conjuring book, expect her in|stantly?
Now i'le pronounce you master of your wishes,
For you shall have—

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: The widdow?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: VVhat is sweeter than the widdow,
You Sir, shall have revenge, and Mr. Maslin
To vex him more, de'e observe I will have the widow, My self.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: You will, and what shall I have?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Sir, you shall have revenge, revenge, the joy
Of flesh and blood, life and delight of nature,
The poor mans Luxury, and the rich mans bath,
Above all wealth or widdows Sir. Mr. Maslin,
I'l tame his blood, and his Estate by Law,
VVhile you shall crack your spleen with mirth and
laughter,
And wonder at my subtill arts to vex him.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: All this is reason.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: This shall be done by Law for the High-Con|stable.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: The Lady's come; this Gentleman
Has studied the black art.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Do you withdraw, and leave me opportunity
To wind the widdow up.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Behind the Hangings;

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Vouchsafe your Servant touch your hand, your lip
Is an ambition more becoming Princes:

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I am not proud, where fair salutes invite me.
I come to give you a little trouble, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Madam command me, to the extent of all
My faculties.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: His faculties? that will carry her,
She is a glittering fairye, but he'le conjure her.
Stay if he takes this prize, what shall have
For all my expences! that's considerable;
Oh, I shall have revenge he says; the widdow
Were much the better▪ but we must be rul'd
By our learned Counsell.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: You have order from
A Gentleman of the City, Mr. Fulba●ke,
To draw up writings, sir—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: A Joynture Madam.
But I receiv'd a Countermand.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: From whom?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: From p●ovidence that would not suffer such
An excellent Lady to be lost, and thrown
Among the City rubbish.

sp.speaker: Mam,
sp.l: Do you know Mr. Fulbanke Sir?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: As much, as I do wonder at his impudence,
And sawcy ambition with his mean deserts
To look at such a blessing; your fortunes
Are worth you● preservation, and a man
Whose art, and serious knowledge in the VVorld
May fence it in from a rapine, and that greater
Enemy to an Estate, pro●usion.
Excuse my plainess Madam.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: 'Tis a Truth.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Can you vouchsafe your smile upon a Ser|vant,
To whose faith and care you safely may commit
A Treasure of more value than the World,
Your self; in me behold him Madam, one
That would devote his soule a Sacrifice
To be for ever burning in those beams,
There is no Law, but in your breast, your lips,
Preserve the Nations Oracle.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: This Language
Doth tast too much of Poetry, take heed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: If this dislike you Madam, I can court you
In a more legall way, and in the name
Of Love and Law arrest you, thus

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Arrest me?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: And hold you fast imprisoned in my arms,
Without or baile or maineprize.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: This does well.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I can do better yet, and put in such
A declaration, Madam, as shall startle
Your merriest blood

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I may put in my answer.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Then comes my replication, to which
You may rejoyne, Currat Lex. shall we?
Joyne issue presently?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: He'l have her se defendend●.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: What do you think of this, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ful▪
sp.l: They are very familiar.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: 'Tis he, the very he, come as my heart
Could wish to his vexation.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: Is this the honest Gentleman
You trusted, Sir;

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Who attends?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: My passion stifles me.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Are you come
My delicate● Devills cut in way? let him not
Approach too near, he can take measure
Of his forehead at this distance.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: These were my fears, marriage had made sure worke,
I was against your stay for tilts, and triumphs.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: 'Tis Mr. Fulbanke.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Would any strumpet vex an honest man thus?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Strumpet; you shall have suell to this jea|lousie.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Excellent Pidgeons! admirable Spiders! ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I'l be revenged.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Cu●●at Lex.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: Excuse me, Sir, I must follow the Law,

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Joy Mr. Fulbanke, and a whole bundle of ba●bies▪ ha, ha, ha.
Your wedding day was notably deferr'd
To be attended with more Ceremony,
And such an antimasq●e of sucking Devills.
He looks like the py'd Pipe● in Germ●ny,
That undertook to cure the Town of Rats,
And now the fry of Vermin dance about him.
I am left to chew my Countrey cud, an asse,
A ridden-empty-pated-sordid Coxcomb:
You do command in chief o're Cuckolds sconce
Or Haven, to which all the Tups strike saile,
And bow in homage to your Soveraigne Antlers.
Most high and mighty halfe moon, Prince of Becos.
And so I kiss your hoof.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Well; if there be money and malice in the City,
Expect a black revenge upon ye all.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: My nimble Lawyer thinks he has got my Lady,
And hugges his happiness, my next worke shall be
To spoile his practice, mischief is my office.
Most noble Alamode,

sp.speaker: Ala,
sp.l: My old acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: I am proud that you will owne me, Sir, your Creature.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: When is this day of Triumph in the City.
For high and mighty Fulba●ke, and your Ladies
So much expected marriage?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: At the Greeke Calends;
My Lady's has left the Alderman allready.
He may now change his Heraldry, and give
In's coat an armed beast at the new bull-ring
In a field dirt.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: whether is she gone prethee?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: To Travers sir, who has yet no Terme for life.
Your hopes thrive I guess in the fair Honoria.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: She's a haggard too.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: Possible?

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: She has gull'd us learnedly,
And took the Scholar, in few months you'le heare
Her brought to bed of Philosophy, she's gone,
And I may as soone hope to re●rive thy Lady,

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: My Lady? with your pardon, gentle sir,
Can you find in your self any warme thought,
Or meaning to my Lady?

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Could I wish
To live, and look at happiness?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: You have been a noble Patron to me.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: What canst thou do?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: Do, I can do the office of a Gentleman,
And you shall go your part, and perhaps owner.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Make me so happy.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: I'l conduct you,
You come i'th opportunity.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: My starres conspire to make me a full hap|piness,
Since, fame spread my intended marriage
With Lady Mammon, methinks the people
Look on me with another face of feare,
And admiration, in my thoughts I see
My self allready in the Throne of Law,
In which the petty purples waite, dispersing
As I incline to frowne, or smile, the fate
Of trembling mortalls,

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: He is return'd.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Where is thy Lady, thou art (I observe) her favourite.
And must be mine;

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: She's in her Chamber sir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Come I will have it so, thou art too humble,

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: 'Tis a becoming Duty, My ambition
Will be to observe the wonder of your happiness,
And how you'l rise to greatness, and to glory,
By matching with my Lady,

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You are not
A stranger to her closset, it will be
An engagement to acquaint me with her temper.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: She is a woman, Sir, but you are wise.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Nay, nay, I must know her nature.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: 'Tis very gentle, she is angell Gold,
And you may bend her as you please, she is
A teeming Lady too.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: What Children?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: All provided for, they'l not trouble you,
She has a thousand friends.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Thou art kind, proceed—

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: You are a Gentleman,
Whose wisdome I may trust, I should not use
This freedom else.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Thou maist tell me any thing.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: She loves to be abroad, and to disperse
Her shine upon some persons that adore her,
That's all her fault, she wo'not be confind, Sir;
And how the softness of your nature will
Consent, to keep her under lock and key—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Umh! if she be so volatile, I must
Hang weight upon her, 'twill be necessary.
Retain thy wisdom and observe my Lady,

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: It is my duty, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: My noble Client.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: I ha not leisure to aske how go causes.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Yours will be heard, the first day of the Term.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: I build upon your care.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You may be confident,
Neglect my Doctor, to whose care, and art
I owe my lungs, and life?

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Oh you are pleasant,
But I am now engag'd, and shall desire
I may be excus'd, you know my Lady Honoria▪

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: She is not sick.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: No, but a Gentleman
Whom she declares most precious to her, is,
(I'th height of expectation, and fair hopes
To have been her husband,) desperately falne Sick,
And now I think on't, 'tis my wonder, you
Made no addresses timely to that Lady.
Men that are eminent in Law, are wont
To be ambitious of Honour.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Oh Sir
It is a maxime in our politicks,
A Judge destroyes a mighty practiser.
When they grow rich, and lazie, they are ripe
For honour.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: You have Sir a swelling fortune.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I have Mammon, I think, and for my owne part
Can easily consent to accept of Lordship.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: If this man take the toy, and dye, she's worth
Your thoughts, my learned in the Laws, I wish
Sir I could serve you.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Nay, nay prethee Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: The Gentleman may suffer,

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: If he dye,
You and I shall be friends, i'le not engage you
To poison him.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: You have more justice.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Yet I should not breake my heart, if he were dead,
And the faire Lady mine, I know not, but
This very mention of her, at this nick
Of time, when her deligh● is taking leave,
Hath a strange operation in my fancye:
You know my constitution, I may want
Your ay'd, but honourably.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: You shall command it.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Then i'l to her instantly, and beare you com|pany.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: You can pretend no visit, being a stranger.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No, I will go under the notion of
Your friend, and fellow Doctor, one o'th Colledge.

sp.speaker: Doc,
sp.l: You may do so.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I need not shift my habit.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: And what then?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Observe, and see the Motions of my Lady,
Who knows but I may feel her'pulse? I prophecie
Something will follow fortunate. If I thrive
Thou shalt be King of Cos, my learn'd Hyppocrates
And I will be thy Servant.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: 'Tis too early to court her.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: 'Tis a fault of modesty
In men to think so. Women are no fools,
And howsoe're they bridle it, 'tis p●ovidence
'T entertain new comforts, I have heard
A modest Gentleman say, that made his love
Known to a Lady e're her husbands flesh
VVas cold i'th crust, I meane new cofind up,
But he had a repulse, the answer was
He came too late, the widdow had been promis'd
The day before.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: If you be so resolv'd,
I'le waite upon you, Sir:

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: The rest to my kind starres, come wee'l take Coach.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Presume to lock me up? thou ha'st my Jew|ells.
I'l leave him instantly.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: He fears his tenure,
And would secure your Ladyship from starting,
But this doth very well become your prudence,
To quit the house e're he improve his interest,
By some new quirk in Law.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: A noble Gentleman!
And one that honours you religiously.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: You much obliege me sir, and I look on, you
Design'd by providence my preserver; wee'le
Into t'h Countrey instantly.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Any whether, excellent Phantasme!
I am your Servant Madam, to wait on you
Through the VVorld.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: I was borne to make you—
A foole, or I am mistaken.
This is his Clarke, and spie upon your person.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: How the rascall squints upon us?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Tell Mr. Travers,
The Bird is flowne, commend me to his night-cap,
I shanot see him till the next vacation,
So farewell penny a sheet.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: And dost heare? bid him
Provide new locks and keys, and barres and bolts,
And cap the Chimney, least my Lady fly
O●t at the Lover hole, so commend us to
The precious owle your Master.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: One token from me.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: You have trusted me with tokens of remem|brance,
I would my Master had received them in
His propria persona, to have thank'd you.
Their toes are somewhat harder than my haunches;
But this is nothing to the generall damage,
If our great Lady Mammon be run from us;
VVhich I believe, as sure, as I am waking,
And have been kick'd, the most convincing argu|ment.
All our hopes come to this? our mighty hopes
Huge as a Mountain, shrunke into a wart?
VVe are undone, and may go hang our selves.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I was too blame, my curiosity
Now suffers for the Triall of his vertue;
And he too apprehensive, when I chid
The Ambition of his love, made himself past
The cure of my affection.
Sir, you are welcome:

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Madam, I presum'd
To bring another able Doctor with me
For his consult, in case there may be danger.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: You have very much oblieged me.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: She is a very gallant Lady!
●nspight of all the clouds that dwell upon her.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: VVho waits there? shew these Doctors Mr. Alworths
Chamber, there is another Gentleman within
Of your profession; your cares shall find
〈◊〉 gratitude becoming both my self,
●nd your owne worth, and I may tell you Doctor,
●f it may give the least addition to
Your Cheerfulness, in his you will preserve my life.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Madam, retain but your own vertue●, and be confident.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Poor Alworth, there is left no other way
To pay my satisfaction to thy merits,
But with my sorrow for thy sufferings,
A●d what will be thought pious to thy memory,
●f Fate translate thee hence: ha, he is returned.
What think you Sir?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I wish he could sleep Madam, I am for his sleep,
●t would be a benefit, truth is, I much fear him▪
But 'tis not prudence (give me boldness Madam)
To let this Sorrow play too much a Tyrant
On your fair cheek: This shews him precious t● you,
If the Srars envying his converse on Earth,
Court him to their bright Dwellings, you must be
Arm'd with a noble Fortitude, and consent
To let him rise a Constellation there,
And not impair your self, who were not meant
To be snatch'd hence, by over-hasty sorrow,
But live the worlds best Ornament.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Did you say
That sleep would much advantage him? What think● you
Of some soft murmures of the Lute, or Voyce?
I have heard the purlings of a spring will make
Our senses glide into a dream I have a Page did use
To please him much.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: What think you on her?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I think? I cannot think too much upon her.
But I'll not leave her thus, her very presence
Is able to recover him.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Let me tell you Sir,
I finde no Danger in him, be then counsel'd
Not to betray your self, you finde his temper
Not apt for your design, Expect a time—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I love her infinitely. Mammon is a Blouze,
A deformed Gypsie, didst ere see her Doctor?
She paints abominably, ey'd like a Tumbler,
Her Nose has all the colours of the Rainbow,
Her Lips are blue, and her teeth straddle, you
May pick'em with a bed-staff.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: You describe
An Elegant person.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: But Honoria
Has all perfections. Stay, what fees de'e think
I have had of you since our acquaintance, there's
A purse of gold—no ceremony, I am still
In thy arrears for bringing me to see
This wonder of her sex.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: You are not wilde.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Your cause shall cost you nothing too, that ended,
Quarrel with all the Countrey, your Law's paid for.
Serve me but now, I'll be thy slave for ever.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I now suspect the Lawyer is short liv'd,
Men of his Robe are seldom guilty of
These restitutions, but who can help it?
If I knew any handsome way to serve him,
He has oblig'd me.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: He'l shame us all,
He's zealously perswading the poor Gentleman
To dye with all speed, and tells him stories
Of Heaven, what a fine place it is, and what
Excellent company the Angels are;
What a base Prison to a noble Soul
The world is, nothing right under the Moon,
Or worth a manly thought; and presently
He courts my Lady, and falls into such raptures
In her commendation. The Gentleman
(Whose Crisis is not desperate, if I
Have any Judgement) smiles at his folly.
They'r both here.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: He's a Gentleman, whose condition,
And as he has relation to your favours,
May invite some passion: But you are wiset
Then to condemn your self to solitude,
And for his absence to despise mankinde;
Be just for your own sake, and Madam, look
Beyond his Hearse, with pitty on the living,
'Mongst which, you cannot want, as just admirers,
And some that may be worth your second thoughts.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: What mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I mean your second choice.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: This language makes your Charity suspected.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: You are too violent, leave us a while.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Your friend is full of counsel.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: You have goodnes,
To place an innocent sense upon his language,
I know he has much honour to your person,
And 'tis sometimes as necessary, to
Advise the living to preserve their health,
Which their immoderate sorrows would consume,
As cure the languishing patient.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Now Madam,
Your grief is useless to him, he is dead.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Dead?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: She Faints.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: A blessed Opportunity!
There is a Coach at door will hold us all,
My dearest Esculapian, help, and finde
A bounty will deserve it.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I Have secur'd the person of Honoria,
At my Mannor in the Countrey, who believes
Her Alworth dead, and must be allowed some time
For that digestion. I have made known
My self, and the affection which engag'd me.
But though my Lady Mammon have a place
Beneath her in my thoughts; on better counsel,
I think it wisdom to preserve my interest
In her, already mine by her consent,
And the great plea of Law, Possession.
If I can make the Lady Honoria sure,
She shall be my wife, and that my Concubine,
Rare, Excellent!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.l: Oh Sir, y'are welcome home.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Thou look'st with a warp'd face.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.l: You can resolve me,
Is there no case, wherein a man, without
Impeachment to his Credit or his Conscience,
May be allowed to hang himself?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: What's the matter?
Thou art not desperate?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.l: I know not, but
I finde some inclinations to Hemp.
You are my Master, I may be concern'd
To follow a good example.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Leave your fooling,
How does my Lady Mammon?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: There's the business.
My Lady Mammon is Sir—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: What, what is she?

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: She is my Lady Mammon, yet I lye,
She is not mine, I would she were your Worships,
I know you will be mad, but it must out,
My Ladies gone.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: Run quite away Sir,
With a glib Gentleman came to visit her,
And the young spirit that did wait upon her.
Without much ceremony, she would have your Worship
Provide more locks, and keys, and bars, and bolts.
I tell you Sir, Verbatim, for a need
I have it all in pedescript.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Mammon gone?

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: What think you Sir, of a ne Exeat Reg|num?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Gone? my vexation? no pursuit will reach her,
Give her the start, and she'll out-strip the Devil.
These things will turn me wild, but that's no cure,
I must be a man agen, and tame this passion,
Her loss may have recompence, if Honoria
Can yet be gain'd, my hopes are full of blossom,
I'll return instantly, come you along Sir▪

div.stage: Enter Men carrying burthens of Money.
div.l: What are these? ha? 'tis money, whence I pray

sp.l: From the City Sir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: But whether goes it?
Do you not observe
Us march in rank and file, this money goes
To maintain many honest Gentlemen
That want it, that will fight, and do fine things
For all our goods; you are a fool I see,
And do not know the Law.

sp.speaker: T●a.
sp.l: What Law?
Club Law.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: How's that?
The Cannon Law, do I speak loud enough?
The Gentlemen behinde will tell you more.

div.stage: Enter Fulbank and Citizens, other men waiting with Bags of money.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I like not this: let us to horse immediately.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: 'Tis high time, that we tame the insolence,
Of this long Robe, these Princes of the Law
Will invade all our Liberties and Fortunes.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.l: Presume to take our Lady Mammon from us?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: And as I hear, she's closely hurried
To a Castle in the Countrey, made a Prisoner.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.l: I should consent the City be still great,
And our names spread, like our ambitions,
But we not prudently consider, whom
We trust with our revenge—

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Our Mercenaries,
Who findes 'em buff, and iron, and when they
Come lame and halting home, who shall provide 'em
Good Hospitals, and old shirts to make lint on?
When we please, we can scatter all the Regiments▪
If we but rein our purses.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.l: I am clear
There is no other way to carry on
The work, the sword strikes Terrour, and who knows,
The body of the Law being vast, and powerful,
Might (if not timely thus prevented) raise
Considerable strength and opposition.
But thus we stifle all, and having once
Recovered Mammon, we are Princes.
Omnes, Princes!

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.l: Where shall we dine Colonel? I ha lost
My credit at the Ordinary, this Town
I think is onely scituate to starve in.
What are these?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: They have City faces.

sp.speaker: Squa.
sp.l: And are a thought too handsome to be Ser|jeants,
They have serious eyes upon us, and move to us.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Would you with me Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Yes Sir, with you.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: May I take boldness Sir, to ask your name?

sp.speaker: Squa.
sp.l: My name?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: For no harm Sir, you are a Souldier,
And I presume have had commands.

sp.speaker: Squa.
sp.l: What then Sir, keep off.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: I come in friendship, and mean all
Civilities to your person: De'e want money?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.l: Would you have your pate broke?
For such a foolish question to a Gentleman?
I do want money Sir, you wo'not furnish me.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: Do not mistake your self, come hither sirrah,
VVill this do you much harm?

sp.speaker: Squ,
sp.l: Harm! pray be covered. Miracles! De'e know
VVhat you have done?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: An act of Justice,
To call it Charity, would stain your honour,
I look for no security.

sp.speaker: Squa.
sp.l: Not a note under my hand never to pay you,
VVhat must I do for all this Sir? whose throat
VVould you have cut now? these fine Devils
Must do something.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: Buy you new cloathes, a better sword▪
The Leather of your boots are of two families,
You may want linnen too, get fresh, and part
VVith bosom friends.

sp.speaker: Squa.
sp.l: I have more stowage.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: And I'll employ it, at your service Sir,

sp.speaker: Squa.
sp.l: VVhat will become of me?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: Nay Sir, I must tell you,
Y'are like to have more of this.

sp.speaker: Squa.
sp.l: Has he no cloven foot?
This is the rarest Citizen!

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: De'e hear Sir?
VVe are making of our VVill, and in the humour
That now predominates, that Gentleman
May be the Cities heir.

sp.speaker: Squa.
sp.l: VVere it not pity this should be a dream now?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: You have commission, and full instructi|ons,
Be sure you do not pinch to spare our purses,
Our Money grows, we are fain to weed the silver,
Our men are rank, and rot upon the stalk
For want of cutting, every drum-stick is
A Lime-twig, they are mad for innovations,
Pray know my brother Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I am his faithful servant.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: One of the Birds, that keep the Capitol,
Our feathers are all at your service Gentlemen,
VVhen you have pluck'd and pick'd us well, you may
Give order for our roasting, we are tame Sir.

sp.speaker: Squa.
sp.l: Beshrew me an understanding fellow.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: VVe have no more to say, 'tis the Publique cause,
Bring Mammon home, and we will rout the Laws.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: And so we'll pray for you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: For your selves Gentlemen, I do conceive
VVe shall do well enough.
Captain Squanderbag,
VVhat think you of this change? silver comes in
Upon us like a Sea.

sp.speaker: Squa.
sp.l: An ebb must be expected, I hate naturally
This mettal of the Moon, ●●is a pale flood,
VVould I were in Pactolus streams, or Tagus,
There were a lasting Element.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: VVhat do you
Think of these Golden Images?

sp.speaker: Squa.
sp.l: I honour the bright sons of Sol.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Pity these Gentlemen should want Civil VVar,
They take such pains, and pay so heartily,
VVe have much to do o'th sudden.

sp.speaker: Squa.
sp.l: This long peace
Hath made us tame i'th world, let e'm now pay 'fort.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: VVe are emergent from our shades, let's rise.
VVith subtil motion, treasure makes men wise.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.l: She has gull'd the Lawyer too.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Most excellent,
I do adore her wit, and will she visit
The Cou●trey, ha? come neerer,

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.l: I have repented Sir, my past neglect?
And made this satisfaction by my Counsel,
VVhich has prevail'd, and now she comes to you Sir,
VVith pure affection to your self, the Lady
Mammon is onely yours.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Did you hear that?
The Empress of the world is coming hither
To me, with pure affection to my person,
We are her Vassals.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.l: 'Cause the times are dangerous
Sir, she comes private, but one Gentleman
That knows not her design, I ever thought
You were born to be a great man.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: We'll go forth to meet her.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.l: By no means Sir, 'twas her desire,
You should be onely thus prepar'd, I'll tell her.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: 'Tis my happiness,
Shall I be at last a Dominus fac totum?
There's Latin for you Neighbours, I am inspir'd
With Languages, with all things, and you shall,
The poorest Copiholder of my Tenants
Be allow'd a Concubine.
Whaw! then we shall
Be Turks Sir.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Turks? the Turks a Civil Gentleman.
But no Christiam.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Ye'e are a fool, we
Must all come to't if the times hold, and my
Deer Mammon stay with us.
Bless me a Turk!
Is that such a matter; why you, and I,
And the best on us, are but Turks, if you
Take us one way.
I grant, as we are brethren, and
Turks, another way, and worse—

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Let me see, how shall I consume my wealth?
VVhat think you of building Sir a Church?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: A Church? and give it my own name to save
A Consecration, No, no, I must do
Something to shame the Chronicles—silence,
I'll build another Town in every County,
In midst of that, a most magnificent Colledge,
To entertain men of most eminent wit,
To invent new Religions.
That were excellent, we want Religion extreamly.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Can none of you invent? I think I must
Keep men in pension to project me ways
To spend my gold.
Pave all the high-way with't,
'Twould be excellent for Travellers.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: I'll pave a street, that shall run cross the Island,
From Sea to Sea, with Pearl build a bridge
From Dover Cliff to Callis.
A Draw-bridge?
This may be done, but I am of opinion
VVe shan'ot live to see't.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: 'Twon'ot be want of money, but of time,
Meer time, to finish it; my Lady Mammon,
Believe it, can do all things; for your parts,
But think what you would have, I say no more:
If she smile but upon you, you are made,
And may go sleep, and when you wake, run mad
VVith telling of your money—ha? 'tis she.
I Charge you kneel, and kiss her hand,
My Lady Mammon!

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: VVelcome to my heart, Madam.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Is my Lady in earnest?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: You have done me Sir a favour, I'm at home,
And disingage your further service; I
VVish you a fair retreat.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Do you hear Madam?
You will not thus reward me, after all
My travel and attendance?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: 'Tis my meaning,
Nor will it Sir, be safe to lose much time,
These have a natural antipathy
To men of your fine making.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.l: 'Tis Alamode the Courtier,
VVhom my Lady has onely made her property,
To be part of her convoy.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: You wo'not marry him?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I think I sha'll not,
I must not be confin'd, while there is ayr,
And men to change.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: How Master Courtier?

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.l: They'l toss him in a blanket.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: As long as you please Madam, he's wel|come,
And he shall eat, if you frown, he must vanish,
Or I have Canibals that will devour him;
VVith his sword, boots treble tann'd and spurs up|on 'em.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Sure I dream, but Madam
You wo'not play the Cockatrice thus wo'me.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: If you will stay, upon your good beha|viour;
I may dispense some private favour—

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Good, excellent VVhore, I'll stay to observe her humor.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: I'll be your guide Madam,
On, go before, and bid'm ring the bells,
For bonefires, 'twill be time enough at night
To burn up all the Villages about us.

sp.speaker: Ala.
sp.l: Indeed it shall be yours: Sir, you are too civil.

div.stage: Enter Travers● and Dash the Clark.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Intreat my Lady hither, and attend her,
I did embrace too much, Mammon is lost,
If my stars prosper my ambition
To Honoria, I forgive their future influence.
sp.stage: A Discovery of Treasures and Iewels.
sp.l: Here is a blaze to melt a frozen soul.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: VVhat is my Jaylors pleasure with his Pri|soner?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: That character doth wound your servant, Ma|dam,
● am your Prisoner, by the fate of Love,
Condemnd to everlasting chains, my heart
Consumes at every frown, and I beg now
Not to be happy owner of that beauty,
●ince you decree my Exile, but to dye,
Collect up so much terrour in a look,
●nd from that Throne of Majestie, your eyes,
●art forth a flame of wrath so high, it may
●urn me to ashes, I'll submit your Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I have no thoughts so impious, to destroy
〈◊〉 life that may be happy, if you be not
Your own Tormenter.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Those words have a sound of mercy, Ma|dam.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Cruelty and honour
●re inconsistent.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I taste Heaven,
Already, a warm stream descends upon
My timorous heart; Oh pause, let me consider
How much I am behinde in worth, to know
VVhat change hath blest it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Change?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Let me but touch
●our white hand, were my breath the Treasure
●f all the East, no other Altar should
Have Incense, I am lost to finde the sweetness.
For every smile I drop a Pearl, these Diamonds
Are pale, and beg a lustre from your Eyes,
VVear them, and be their ornament: I'll rifle
My Indies for more wealth, and when I have,
With giving up my soul, purchas'd a kiss
Of bright Honoria, from my dust at one,
One pittying look upon me, I ascend
A new Creation from your Eye.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: What means
This rapture? what would all this passionate noise?
Expound, I am still Honoria.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Oh say but mine.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Sir, shut up your shop,
Your gay temptations wo'not take.
